results.title: Vivaldi: the Four Seasons
results.creator_credit: Elkins Organization, Le'an Films, Harry Waterson, Eitan Even and Allan Miller
results.brief_description: A stunnning performance of Vivaldi’s Four Seasons by violinists Isaac Stern (Spring), Pinchas Zukerman (Summer), Shlomo Mintz (Autumn), Itzhak Perlman (Winter) supported by the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra and conducted by Zubin Mehta as part of the Huberman Festival staged at the Frederick R. Mann Auditorium, Tel Aviv in 1983. This truly beautiful music is interspersed with acompanying images of Israel and Palestine depicting the mood of each of the seasons.

results.title: Vivaldi's Venice
results.brief_description: Six 18th century concerti of Vivaldi sustain the sensuous poetry of the camera as it reflects Venice’s glories and variety of moods through Vivaldi’s, The 4 Seasons - Winter-Autumn Concerto. (Award: “Osella D’Argento” 30th International Exhibition of Cinematographic Art, Venice, August 1969)

results.title: Vitamin C
results.creator_credit: Michael Coyle and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Home Economics”
During the winter many of us suffer from a lack of Vitamin C. What foods are the best sources of Vitamin C and how can we preserve it in our cooking?

results.title: Visual story telling
results.creator_credit: John A. Givins, Lynn John and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Video tech”.
This program presents a structured look at the practice and technique of video story telling. It looks at the sequencing of shots and how they work to advance a story, the planning of shots, the shooting of a sequence and the placement of the camera when shooting. It focusses on continuity and the factors to watch when editing so that shots will flow from one to the other and not seem illogical in the finished product.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John A. Givins, Lynn John and KTV Productions

results.title: Visual perception
results.brief_description: Dr. Hadley Cantrill of Princeton University discusses his investigations of the effects of some of our assumptions on what we see. Shows balloons that seem to move when in reality they are being inflated and deflated, or illuminated and darkened.

results.title: Visual documents
results.creator_credit: Sandra Ostertag, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, CBS, KOCE-TV (Television station : Huntington Beach, Calif.) and Coast Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 16 of Series “The Photographic vision”.
Traces the historical development of photography as a means of documentation and emphasizes the importance of photographic records in the fields of science, law and industry.

results.title: Visit to Picasso = Visite a Picasso
results.creator_credit: Paul Haesaerts, Art et Cinema and Jean Van Raemdonck
results.brief_description: A study of the work of Picasso showing the development of his technique from his ‘blue’ period, through Cubism to abstraction. A series of paintings, sculptures and ceramics in the first part of the film lead to a personal interview with the artist in his studio at Vallauris in which he gives an unusual demonstration of his technique by sketching white paint on an invisible sheet of glass placed between himself and the camera. Examples of the artist’s work in the film are from the Musee d’Antibes at Vallauris which is devoted almost entirely to the exhibition of Picasso’s work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Haesaerts, Art et Cinema and Jean Van Raemdonck

results.title: Visit to an airport
results.creator_credit: Dave Gibson, Gibson Film Productions and Yvonne MacKay
results.brief_description: Two children visit an airport and learn about various aspects of its operation; luggage checks, plane checks, take-off procedures, control tower operations, food preparation and movement of food into the planes.
